titleStmt.title: Inscription in honour of Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Arcadius, Honorius from Side by Tatianus praet. praefect

summary.term: Honorary inscription to the emperors Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Arcadius, and Honorius

layout.p: The base was inscribed on one field.
layout.rs: Undamaged: the inscription is complete and has 17 lines, of which 16 are preserved. The name of the awarder has been deliberately erased, but remains partially legible.

history.provenance: The base was found on the beach of Side, near the theatre

div.p: “Agli imperatori della Terra sotto il sole, trionfanti, i nostri signori Valentinianus, Teodosius, Arcadius, perpetui Augusti, e Flavius Honorius, nobilissimo, il chiarissimo Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, prefetto dei sacri praetoria, realizzò con la consueta devozione, quando era governatore…, il chiarissimo consolare.”

“To the emperors of the Earth under the sun, triumphant, our masters Valentinianus, Theodosius, Arcadius, the eternal Augusti, and Flavius Honorius, the most noble, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, of clarissimus rank, prefect of the sacred praetoria, set this up with the customary devotion, when ... was consularis (of Pamphylia) of clarissimus rank.”

“Aux empereurs de la Terre sous le soleil, triomphateurs, nos seigneurs Valentinianus, Theodosius, Arcadius, Augustes perpétuels, et Flavius Honorius, le très noble, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, clarissime préfet des prétoires sacrés, a réalisé avec la dévotion habituelle, quand il était gouverneur..., le clarissime consulaire.”

Today the inscription is lost. It was carved on a statue base as a dedication in honour of the emperors Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Arcadius Augusti and Honorius nobilissimus (puer). It was found on the beach of the ancient city of Side, near the roman theatre. It was described by the British architect Charles R. Cockerell (1788-1863) who traveled in the eastern Mediterranean between 1810 and 1817 and who visited the southern coast of ancient Anatolia (Turkey) in 1811 (cf. Pearce, Ormrod 2017).

The same introductory formula of dedication to the four emperors (lines 1-4) «emperors of the land under the sun» (τῆς ὑφ’ ἡλίῳ γῆς αὐτοκράτορες), can also be found in Tatianus’ inscriptions for Arcadius at Aphrodisias (PPRET 83), for Valentinianus II at Aphrodisias (PPRET 84) and in the inscriptions to the four emperors at Antinoupolis (PPRET 86). The awarder also dedicated similar inscriptions individually to each of the four emperors in Aphrodisias (Caria) (see PPRET 82, 83, 84). The inscription in Antinoupolis (PPRET 86) is a ‘twin’ inscription, identical to ours in Side in Pamphylia. Tatianus seems to have won the collaboration of cities in different provinces of his prefecture in order to create a series of monuments to the emperors during his office (388-392 AD). The name of the governor of Pamphylia who actually made this monument in Side has been erased. It was probably a client of Tatianus (see below). But in Antinoupolis the name of Fl. Septimius Eutropius v.c., praeses Thebaidos (PLRE I, p. 318), remained intact. Since his office is dated to 388/390 AD, it is possible that all these monuments were completed at this time.

The name of the prefect Tatianus was erased (linn. 10-11). It was restored by Robert (1948, p. 52) on the model of a similar inscription in Antinoupolis (PPRET 86),that names all the four emperors being honoured at the same time, as in our inscription. Tatianus was a distinguished pagan, who was made the eastern praetorian prefect in 388 AD and fell from power in 392 AD. Between June 30th and August 26th 392 AD, he was suddenly deposed and condemned for embezzlement (in reality maiestas). He suffered damnatio memoriae and banishment to Lycia. He was rehabilitated posthumously by his grandson at Aphrodisias (PPRET 91). His whole career is recorded in ascending order of importance from praeses (ἡγεμών) to praefectus (ἔπαρχος) in PPRET 87. Inside the text of our inscription from Side (ll. 13-14) a reference to a pagan ritual of dedication appears: «the usual offerings» (τῇ συνήθει καθοσιώσει, lines 8-9), referring to the pagan practices that accompanied the ceremony. The group of dedications by Tatianus (PPRET 82-86) always uses this same peculiar formula.
